query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Chi poria mai pur con parole sciolte 2 dicer del sangue e de le piaghe a pieno 3 ch’i’ ora vidi, per narrar più volte?
4 Ogne lingua per certo verria meno 5 per lo nostro sermone e per la mente 6 c’hanno a tanto comprender poco seno.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Who could ever, with unfettered words, 2 fully tell of the blood and the wounds 3 that I saw then, to recount them many times?
4 Surely every tongue would fail 5 in our speech and in our minds, 6 which have too little capacity to comprehend so much.
**Cornish:**
1 Piu poria bythkyn gans gerva dowr 2 leverel a’n gwaedh ha’n wonnow plen 3 a welas vy dhe’n eur, rag leverel hen?
4 Pub ger lavar a via bythkyn feth 5 rag an lavarow hag an menow 6 a wra dhe vesa dhe komprehendya kemmys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
7 S’el s’aunasse ancor tutta la gente 8 che già, in su la fortunata terra 9 di Puglia, fu del suo sangue dolente
10 per li Troiani e per la lunga guerra 11 che de l’anella fé sì alte spoglie, 12 come Livïo scrive, che non erra,
13 con quella che sentio di colpi doglie 14 per contastare a Ruberto Guiscardo; 15 e l’altra il cui ossame ancor s’accoglie
16 a Ceperan, là dove fu bugiardo 17 ciascun Pugliese, e là da Tagliacozzo, 18 dove sanz’ arme vinse il vecchio Alardo;
19 e qual forato suo membro e qual mozzo 20 mostrasse, d’aequar sarebbe nulla 21 il modo de la nona bolgia sozzo.
query.result:
**English:**
7 If all the people were gathered together again 8 who once, in the fortunate land 9 of Puglia, grieved for their blood
10 because of the Trojans and the long war 11 that made such great spoils of rings, 12 as Livy writes, who does not err,
13 with that people who felt the pain of blows 14 for opposing Robert Guiscard; 15 and the other people whose bones are still gathered
16 at Ceperano, where every Puglian lied, 17 and there at Tagliacozzo, 18 where the old Alardo conquered without weapons;
19 and if each person showed his pierced or severed limb, 20 it would be nothing compared to 21 the foul manner of the ninth ditch.
**Cornish:**
7 Ma’th eth oll bobel gwrysset gans onan 8 a veu, wartha’n tir ervys, 9 a Pugli, a veu dhe’n gwaedh dolenni
10 rag an Trojanow ha’n hir vresel 11 a wrug an meudhas kemmys spolyow uhel, 12 dell Livy a skrif, nebmes erri,
13 gans an re a welas an poen a’n golwow 14 rag omsettya Ruberto Guiscardo; 15 ha’n arall an re a’n eskern a wra gwrysset
16 dhe Ceperan, le mayth pub Pugli a veu gelwydh, 17 ha’n le mayth dhe Tagliacozzo, 18 le mayth an hen Alardo a veu trehedh heb armow;
19 ha’th pyw a welas y ael a veu trehedh po torret, 20 ni via nevra kemmys dhe gomparya 21 an fordh a’n nawves bolgia soth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Già veggia, per mezzul perdere o lulla, 23 com’ io vidi un, così non si pertugia, 24 rotto dal mento infin dove si trulla.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Already I see, through losing half or all, 23 how I saw one, not pierced in such a way, 24 split from the chin down to where one breaks wind.
**Cornish:**
22 Meur a welaf, rag kolli hanter po oll, 23 dell welas vy unn, heb pertugya kemmys, 24 torret a’n gen dhe’n le mayth y trulla.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Tra le gambe pendevan le minugia; 26 la corata pareva e ’l tristo sacco 27 che merda fa di quel che si trangugia.
query.result:
**English:**
25 His entrails hung down between his legs; 26 his heart and the wretched sack 27 that makes dung of what is swallowed were visible.
**Cornish:**
25 Ynter y gesow a wra y vennow ow pendya; 26 y corata a wra gwelys ha’n sak trist 27 a wra gwruthyl merdha a’n peth a wra strewydh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Mentre che tutto in lui veder m’attacco, 29 guardommi e con le man s’aperse il petto, 30 dicendo: «Or vedi com’ io mi dilacco!
31 vedi come storpiato è Mäometto! 32 Dinanzi a me sen va piangendo Alì, 33 fesso nel volto dal mento al ciuffetto.
query.result:
**English:**
28 While I was intent on seeing everything in him, 29 he looked at me and with his hands tore open his chest, 30 saying: “Now see how I tear myself apart!
31 See how Mohammed is mutilated! 32 Ali goes weeping before me, 33 his face split from chin to forelock.
**Cornish:**
28 Tra veus vy owth oll ynno dhe welas, 29 y welas vy ha gans y dowrnow y agoras y brust, 30 ow leverel: “Wela bythkyn della vy owth owth omdilacka!
31 Wela bythkyn della vy Mäometto a veu storpya! 32 Rag y blaen vy yma Alì owth omwetha, 33 Y’n fas a veu torret a’n gen dhe’n ciuffet.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 E tutti li altri che tu vedi qui, 35 seminator di scandalo e di scisma 36 fuor vivi, e però son fessi così.

Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Un diavolo è qua dietro che n’accisma 38 sì crudelmente, al taglio de la spada 39 rimettendo ciascun di questa risma,
40 quand’ avem volta la dolente strada; 41 però che le ferite son richiuse 42 prima ch’altri dinanzi li rivada.
query.result:
**English:**
37 A devil is here behind who slaughters them 38 so cruelly, at the cut of the sword 39 sending each of this ream back,
40 when we have turned the sorrowful road; 41 because the wounds are closed up 42 before another comes before them.
**Cornish:**
37 Yn jebel a wra yma'n keffrys ow tostya 38 mar serth, orth an kledha a'n kledha 39 ow tossel orth pub onan a'n keffrys ma,
40 pan wrello ni an fordh dolorus; 41 rag an wonnow a wra gesys 42 kyns na wra unn aral orth aga.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Ma tu chi se’ che ’n su lo scoglio muse, 44 forse per indugiar d’ire a la pena 45 ch’è giudicata in su le tue accuse?».
query.result:
**English:**
43 But you who are you who muse upon the rock, 44 perhaps to delay going to the punishment 45 that is judged upon your accusations?».
**Cornish:**
43 Mes ty, pyw os ow pew orth an garrek, 44 mar pleg dhe lettya dhe vos dhe benas 45 owth yw breusys orth dha gonisogeth?».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 «Né morte ’l giunse ancor, né colpa ’l mena», 47 rispuose ’l mio maestro, «a tormentarlo; 48 ma per dar lui esperïenza piena,
49 a me, che morto son, convien menarlo 50 per lo ’nferno qua giù di giro in giro; 51 e quest’ è ver così com’ io ti parlo».
query.result:
**English:**
46 «Neither death has reached him yet, nor fault leads him», 47 replied my master, «to torment him; 48 but to give him full experience,
49 to me, who am dead, it is necessary to lead him 50 through Hell down here from circle to circle; 51 and this is true just as I speak to you».
**Cornish:**
46 «Marow nyns yw ef ow kovos, nagha growdh ef», 47 a leveris ow mastir, «rag dhe benas; 48 mes rag dhe roi ef a skiens plen,
49 dhe'vy, ow marow, yw gesys dhe ledyas 50 dre Infern ama yma a-woles a-woles; 51 ha henna yw gwir kepar ha'm leveris dhe'vys».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Più fuor di cento che, quando l’udiro, 53 s’arrestaron nel fosso a riguardarmi 54 per maraviglia, oblïando il martiro.
query.result:
**English:**
52 More than a hundred who, when they heard him, 53 stopped in the ditch to look at me 54 in wonder, forgetting their torment.
**Cornish:**
52 Moy es yntra kans dhe'gans, pan glewis ef, 53 a sevis yn an fos rag dhe welas 54 a-dhiwedhes, ow angofya aga boen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 «Or dì a fra Dolcin dunque che s’armi, 56 tu che forse vedra’ il sole in breve, 57 s’ello non vuol qui tosto seguitarmi,
58 sì di vivanda, che stretta di neve 59 non rechi la vittoria al Noarese, 60 ch’altrimenti acquistar non saria leve».
query.result:
**English:**
55 «Now then tell friar Dolcino to arm himself, 56 you who perhaps will soon see the sun, 57 if he does not want to follow me here soon,
58 with such provisions that the harsh snow 59 does not bring victory to the Novarese, 60 which otherwise would not be easy to acquire».
**Cornish:**
55 «Wosa, lever dhe'fras Dolcin dhe armya, 56 ty a welo an howl a-varr, 57 mar nyns eus ow holya dhe'm sevel ama,
58 gans dha voos, rag an ergh a'n ergh a'n ergh 59 nyns eus dhe Novarese an treus, 60 rag mar nyns eus, nyns eus dhe gwaynya».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Poi che l’un piè per girsene sospese, 62 Mäometto mi disse esta parola; 63 indi a partirsi in terra lo distese.
query.result:
**English:**
61 After he raised one foot to go away, 62 Muhammad said these words to me; 63 then he stretched it out on the ground to depart.
**Cornish:**
61 Wosa ef a sevis unn troos rag mos, 62 Mahowmet a leveris an gerow ma; 63 wosa henna ef a estynis orth an nor dhe mos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Un altro, che forata avea la gola 65 e tronco ’l naso infin sotto le ciglia, 66 e non avea mai ch’una orecchia sola,
67 ristato a riguardar per maraviglia 68 con li altri, innanzi a li altri aprì la canna, 69 ch’era di fuor d’ogne parte vermiglia,
70 e disse: «O tu cui colpa non condanna 71 e cu’ io vidi su in terra latina, 72 se troppa simiglianza non m’inganna,
73 rimembriti di Pier da Medicina, 74 se mai torni a veder lo dolce piano 75 che da Vercelli a Marcabò dichina.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Another, who had his throat pierced 65 and his nose cut off right up to his eyebrows, 66 and who had only one ear left,
67 stopped to look in wonder 68 with the others, and before the others he opened his throat, 69 which was red all over on the outside,
70 and said: «Oh you whom no fault condemns 71 and whom I saw up there in the Latin land, 72 if too much resemblance does not deceive me,
73 remember Pier da Medicina, 74 if you ever return to see the sweet plain 75 that slopes down from Vercelli to Marcabo.
**Cornish:**
64 Un aral, ow treusys oji ef, 65 ha'y tronk oji ef bys y'n keus, 66 ha nag eus ef mes unn kledha,
67 a sevis rag an erel dhe welas 68 gans an erel, ow tos kerensa y'n gann, 69 ow oji rudh a-derri,
70 ha leveris: «O ty, pyw nyns eus growdh ow gondemnya 71 ha'm gweles vy yn Norvys, 72 mar nyns yw kemmysledhans ow trompil,
73 kov dhe Byer a Vedisina, 74 mar teffo dhe welas an plann melyon 75 ow tos a Vercelli dhe Marcabo.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 E fa saper a’ due miglior da Fano, 77 a messer Guido e anco ad Angiolello, 78 che, se l’antiveder qui non è vano,
79 gittati saran fuor di lor vasello 80 e mazzerati presso a la Cattolica 81 per tradimento d’un tiranno fello.
query.result:
**English:**
76 And let the two best from Fano know, 77 Messer Guido and also Angiolello, 78 that, if my foresight here is not in vain,
79 they will be thrown out of their ship 80 and killed near Cattolica 81 through the treachery of a cruel tyrant.
**Cornish:**
76 Ha lever dhe'n dew wella a Fano, 77 dhe Syr Guido ha Angiolello, 78 mar nyns yw ow ragwel orth ama yn fals,
79 ef a wra tewlys a-ves aga lester, 80 ha'gas losow orth y'n Cattolica 81 dre dhortyans unn treusour fella.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 Tra l’isola di Cipri e di Maiolica 83 non vide mai sì gran fallo Nettuno, 84 non da pirate, non da gente argolica.
query.result:
**English:**
82 Between the island of Cyprus and Majorca 83 Neptune never saw such a great disaster, 84 not from pirates, not from the Argive people.
**Cornish:**
82 Yntra ynys Chipri ha Maiolica 83 ny welas Nettun bythkweth fella ma, 84 nagha a-dhiworth morladron, nagha a-dhiworth an bobel Argolic.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Quel traditor che vede pur con l’uno, 86 e tien la terra che tale qui meco 87 vorrebbe di vedere esser digiuno,
88 farà venirli a parlamento seco; 89 poi farà sì, ch’al vento di Focara 90 non sarà lor mestier voto né preco».
query.result:
**English:**
85 That traitor who sees with only one eye, 86 and holds the land that here with me 87 he would like to see deprived of sight,
88 will make them come to a parley with him; 89 then he will ensure that in the wind of Focara 90 they will have no need for vows or prayers.
**Cornish:**
85 An traytour henna a wel gwel gans unnlagha, 86 ha mos an tir na via vi ganso 87 a via karas gweles heb golwg,
88 a wra aga dhe ves gansow; 89 wosa henna, y fensa ev dhe gwyns Focara 90 na via aga gorra ger na pednansow po pregow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 E io a lui: «Dimostrami e dichiara, 92 se vuo’ ch’i’ porti sù di te novella, 93 chi è colui da la veduta amara».
query.result:
**English:**
91 And I to him: "Show me and explain, 92 if you want me to carry news of you above, 93 who is he with the bitter sight".
**Cornish:**
91 Ha my a-dho: "Diskwedh vy ha displeg, 92 mar karas vy aga portha nowodhow a-ugh, 93 pyw yw an onan gans an golwg feth?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Allor puose la mano a la mascella 95 d’un suo compagno e la bocca li aperse, 96 gridando: «Questi è desso, e non favella.
query.result:
**English:**
94 Then he placed his hand on the jaw 95 of one of his companions and opened his mouth, 96 shouting: "This is he, and he does not speak.
**Cornish:**
94 Wosa henna, y gosow y dhorn dhe'y gen 95 unn a'y gompagnons ha'y genow a agor, 96 ow kewsel: "Henna yw ev, ha na leveris".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Questi, scacciato, il dubitar sommerse 98 in Cesare, affermando che ’l fornito 99 sempre con danno l’attender sofferse».
query.result:
**English:**
97 This one, being driven out, drowned doubt 98 in Caesar, affirming that he who is well-supplied 99 has always suffered waiting with loss.
**Cornish:**
97 Henna, wosa'y gorra gorra, a vagas an dowt 98 yn Cesar, ow tysti ow teso an parys 99 a wra gonan goll gans kolledygys sofferes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Oh quanto mi pareva sbigottito 101 con la lingua tagliata ne la strozza 102 Curïo, ch’a dir fu così ardito!
103 E un ch’avea l’una e l’altra man mozza, 104 levando i moncherin per l’aura fosca, 105 sì che ’l sangue facea la faccia sozza,
106 gridò: «Ricordera’ti anche del Mosca, 107 che disse, lasso!, “Capo ha cosa fatta”, 108 che fu mal seme per la gente tosca».
query.result:
**English:**
100 Oh, how terrified he seemed to me, 101 with his tongue cut off in his throat, 102 Curio, who was so bold in speech!
103 And one who had both hands cut off, 104 raising his stumps in the murky air, 105 so that the blood made his face filthy,
106 shouted: "Remember Mosca too, 107 who said, alas!, "A thing done has an end", 108 which was bad seed for the Tuscan people".
**Cornish:**
100 Oh, pyth vyth ow teves sbigotys 101 gans y dowlen tronk yn y stroffa 102 Curio, o veu kemmys o veu hardy!
103 Ha unn arall o veu y unn dhorn ha'y arall dorn tronk, 104 ow leverel y voncherins dre'n ayr foska, 105 kepar ha'n goweth a wrug y enys sozza,
106 a kewsel: "Kov dhe'th bys Mosca ynwedh, 107 o veu leverel, "Penn-fenten yw tra gwrys", 108 o veu had seed drog dhe'n dus toska".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 E io li aggiunsi: «E morte di tua schiatta»; 110 per ch’elli, accumulando duol con duolo, 111 sen gio come persona trista e matta.
query.result:
**English:**
109 And I added to him: "And death to your lineage"; 110 so that he, accumulating grief upon grief, 111 went away like a sad and mad person.
**Cornish:**
109 Ha my a-dho dhe'y: "Ha mernans dhe'th skwat"; 110 rag, dre henna, ow akomulya dol gans dol, 111 ev a veu yma kepar den trist ha matt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Di sé facea a sé stesso lucerna, 125 ed eran due in uno e uno in due; 126 com’ esser può, quei sa che sì governa.
query.result:
**English:**
124 He made a lantern of himself for himself, 125 and they were two in one and one in two; 126 how that can be, He knows who governs it so.
**Cornish:**
124 Ev a wra dhe’y honen latern, 125 ha’y o dew yn unn ha unn yn dew; 126 kepar a alla, henna a wydh pyw a’y rewl.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Quando diritto al piè del ponte fue, 128 levò ’l braccio alto con tutta la testa 129 per appressarne le parole sue,
130 che fuoro: «Or vedi la pena molesta, 131 tu che, spirando, vai veggendo i morti: 132 vedi s’alcuna è grande come questa.
query.result:
**English:**
127 When he was right at the foot of the bridge, 128 he raised his arm high with his whole head 129 to bring his words closer to us,
130 which were: “Now see the grievous punishment, 131 you who, while still breathing, go seeing the dead: 132 see if any is as great as this.
**Cornish:**
127 Pan o veu dhe’y yn onan treus an pons, 128 ev a dhueth y vregh ughel gans y benen 129 rag omdhegas y gerow gwell,
130 o veu: “Weles an poen boes, 131 ty, pan owth analan, owth gweles an merow: 132 gweles po henna yw moyha ages.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 E perché tu di me novella porti, 134 sappi ch’i’ son Bertram dal Bornio, quelli 135 che diedi al re giovane i ma’ conforti.
query.result:
**English:**
133 And so that you may carry news of me, 134 know that I am Bertran de Born, he 135 who gave the young king evil advice.
**Cornish:**
133 Ha rag omdhegas nowydh a’m gena, 134 gwythow henna vy Bertran de Born, henna 135 a roos dhe’n myghtern yonk an fordhow gweth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 Io feci il padre e ’l figlio in sé ribelli; 137 Achitofèl non fé più d’Absalone 138 e di Davìd coi malvagi punzelli.
query.result:
**English:**
136 I made the father and the son rebel against each other; 137 Ahithophel did no more to Absalom 138 and to David with his wicked incitements.
**Cornish:**
136 Me a wrug an tas ha’n mab ribella orth y gila; 137 Ahithophel ny wrug moy dhe Absalom 138 ha dhe David gans y fordhow drog.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Perch’ io parti’ così giunte persone, 140 partito porto il mio cerebro, lasso!, 141 dal suo principio ch’è in questo troncone.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Because I divided people who were so closely united, 140 my brain, alas!, is divided from its source, 141 which is in this trunk.
**Cornish:**
139 Rag omma rannva dus o dus den, 140 rannva vyth omma portha’m empynna, gwell!, 141 a’y dhalleth ow yw y’n tronk ma.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
142 Così s’osserva in me lo contrapasso».
query.result:
**English:**
142 Thus is the punishment of retaliation observed in me.
**Cornish:**
142 Kepar henna yw gweles y’n contrapasso.
